author: mrabino1
content: humor the basics of the following TL;DR question...  based on a quick check of some recent blocks (ignoring the block reward) the miner is presently receiving anywhere from 1-2.2 ETH per block in transaction fees (let's just say 2 eth per block for arguments sake)... after EIP-1559 is deployed, what is the estimate the miner should then receive? clearly it is lower.. I am trying to gauge how much lower...  thank you in advance..

author: sky.cactus
content: My personal guess is that miner bribe demands will be around 1 nanoeth (gwei) per gas.

author: sky.cactus
content: So 12,000,000 nanoeth == 0.012 ETH per block.

author: mrabino1
content: <@301186049323958275> and the rest would be destroyed?

author: sky.cactus
content: Assuming block space demand remains constant, probably about that yes.

author: mrabino1
content: so under PoW, he / her rewards woudl be 2 (block reward currently) + your estimate above.. .. and under PoS, it would be basically 0.02 (block proposal reward) + your estimate above ..

author: mrabino1
content: is that a fair estimate?

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm not sure how block rewards work in PoS, so I cannot comment on that.

author: sky.cactus
content: There isn't *currently* any plan to change the block reward, but that is entirely separate from EIP-1559 and may or may not happen before or after or at the same time as the introduction of 1559.

author: sky.cactus
content: Otherwise, what you said is true.  Mining a block will yield the block reward (whatever that may be) and any miner bribe paid by users for transactions the miner is willing to include.

author: sky.cactus
content: It is possible that miners will demand a higher bribe than 1 nanoeth, though that is the best calculation we have of the opportunity cost of transaction inclusion.

author: mrabino1
content: more than anything i am trying to gauge how far off the fees to the miners would be.. and it looks like two orders of magnitude lower... wow

author: mrabino1
content: (excluding the block reward in either PoS or PoW)

author: sky.cactus
content: Block reward is the incentive for producing blocks at sufficiently high PoW.  Miner bribes are the incentive for including transactions in blocks.

author: sky.cactus
content: As long as transactions are getting included in blocks, the miner bribe is enough.  As long as difficulty is high enough and block are being produced, the block reward is enough.

author: sky.cactus
content: We are *guessing* that 1 nanoeth per gas is enough of a miner bribe to incentivize miners including transactions in blocks and not mining empty blocks, but we won't know for sure until EIP-1559 is launched and market pricing dynamics can kick in.

author: mrabino1
content: gotcha...

author: mrabino1
content: I believe it is an aspect that many folks who are debating if they want to stake or not in ETH2 need to grasp is that the miner bribe would also go to the validator (if I understand it correctly)..

author: sky.cactus
content: It would go to the block producer for a given block I believe (but again, I don't understand PoS well enough to argue that with any sort of authority or confidence).

author: mrabino1
content: (and I am 100% not an authority on the matter).. just exceptionally curious at this stage..

author: sky.cactus
content: My recommendation is to stake or not based on the interest rate you will receive, not on the bribes.  The bribes will likely sit just above opportunity cost, which will likely always be insignificant compared to interest.

author: timbeiko
content: Re: miner fees on PoW, they may be somewhat higher than "txn processing costs" for miners given that so many transactions are for arbitrage purposes. For those, in theory, you want to make sure you are in the next block (vs. next few blocks), and your opportunity cost is quite high. I suspect that will mean those transactions leave a higher than "reasonable" tip to be sure to be included. What % of txn fees that represents is an open question!
